channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: All Aboard to Your Next Adventure! Perl Role in Malta
item.description: Perl programmers rejoice — our client has an office in Malta, and they’re looking for you. As a financial company seeing incredible growth over the last two decades, business is booming and they’re looking to expand their team. If you’ve got an interest in dollars and cents and share their belief that online trading should be available to all, we’ve got the role for you.

item.title: Not All Heroes Wear Capes. Perl in Vienna
item.description: Our client takes the legwork out of the hunt for the best bargain, offering one of the largest product and price comparison platforms in German-speaking countries. They’re looking for a heroic Perl programmer to develop and deliver quality content and all the info users need to find their gadgets for the right price.

item.title: Cooking Up Something Good. Perl role in London
item.description: With a knack for tailoring content to a variety of site aesthetics, our client sets a banquet of advertising delights for over 349 million consumers around the world. If your mouth is watering at the thought of joining this dynamic team and you’re a senior Perl programmer with a solid understanding of Go programming languages, they just might set a place for you at the table.

item.title: A New Adventure is only a Click Away. Perl Developer role, remote within UK
item.description: The client is interested in anyone with experience building web apps in Perl, using one of the major Perl frameworks. If you’re a crack-hand with Catalyst, a Mojolicious master, or a distinguished Dancer, they want you. You’ll be deploying apps your work to AWS, so experience would be handy, and the company’s big on testing, so they’d like you to know your way around Test::More.

item.title: Doers Wanted. Perl Developer role in Pittsburgh, PA
item.description: This client is looking for someone who will design and build the tools their customers need. You’ll coordinate implementation, testing, deployment, and maintenance across multiple systems. If you’re a Perl software engineer who enjoys distilling broadly defined objectives into actionable tasks, this might just be your next career move.

item.title: Weekly Challenge 113
item.description: Simon choice of data format for representing binary tree is very smart. I liked the story behind it too.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 113: Represent-Recreate
item.description: Roger optimisation of the task Represent Integer is the highlight of the blog for me. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 113: sums and trees
item.description: Luca shared the real power of Raku. I loved the solution to Recreate Binary Tree task specially.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 113
item.description: Luis attempt of improving the performance of Represent Integer task is commendable. Keep it up.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge #113
item.description: James code presentation is always the best. It makes reading the code so simple. Also with the detailed task analysis is very handy as well.

item.title: PWC113 - Recreate Binary Tree
item.description: I have high regard for those who present the tree like structure. Although it is not part of the task but some did it on their own. Thank you.

item.title: PWC113 - Represent Integer
item.description: Flavio shared the mathemcatical expression for the task. Lot to learn from his work. Keep up the great work.

item.title: Represent the Differences, Yo!
item.description: I loved the task analysis of Represent Integer. I wonder sometimes, how did I miss it myself.

item.title: The Perl Weekly Challenges, #113
item.description: Welcome Christian and thanks for introducing FunctionalPerl.

item.title: CY's Take on The Weekly Challenge #113
item.description: Cheok always surprised me with something new and this week also we got two very clever solutions. Keep it up.

item.title: Re Re Raku (and Perl)
item.description: I am big fan of Arne for his creative blog title. He is simply the best. This week, we got bonus Perl solutions as well. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge 113
item.description: Adam's use of pack()/unpack() is really interesting. There is always something new to learn. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 113: Recreate Binary Tree
item.description: Abigail is once again at his best. Please check it out.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge: Represent Integer
item.description: Abigail style of expanding the task is much appreciated. There are plenty to learn from his task analysis. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 112
item.description: Aaron took the pain to display the tree like structure. Loved it. Keep it up the great work.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 113
item.description: Enjoy quick recap of last week contributions by the Team PWC dealing with the "Represent Integer" and "Recreate Binary Tree" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 114
item.description: Welcome new week with couple of fun tasks "Next Palindrome Number" and "Higher Integer Set Bits". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read FAQ page.

item.title: Maintaining the Perl 5 Core (Dave Mitchell): Grant Report for March and April 2021
Grant Proposal: Raku Dispatch and Compiler Improvements
April report of the Raku Development Grant of Jonathan Worthington
CAT: Addressing the issues, planning ahead
item.description: This whols story is really tireing. But if you are interested try reading the comments on Reddit.

item.title: Solving simple problems
item.description: Dave is scrobbling using Last.FM. For those who don't know, 'scrobbling' is the act of logging what you're listening to using an external service so that, over time, you build up an accurate picture of who you listen to.

item.title: Grab a distribution tarball from CPAN
item.description: I admit, just a few weeks ago I wrote a partially functioning tool for myself to download and unzip a CPAN distribution. It was fun, but I should have looked for an already existing solution.

item.title: A list of Perl list processing modules
item.description: Is that all? Do you know other Mark should list on his blog? Comment on his blog

item.title: Developing a script in small steps
item.description: A detailed example of taking a big commit and breaking it up into small steps that make the whole process easier to follow.

item.title: Killing spiders - a fresh look on Chowla Numbers
CPANdeps - correction
item.description: Apparently two weeks ago I confused CPANdeps with another of David's ex-projects. cpXXXan was the one that provided older versions of modules for older perls. CPANdeps shows a tree of a module's dependencies, along with test results for your chosen version of perl. The dependency analysis part of that is available on the command line via the `cpandeps` script (distributed with CPAN::FindDependencies) and MetaCPAN shows the first level of dependencies. Since then David found someone to take over maintenance of CPANdeps anyway.

item.title: Improving p5p: Perl is going to stay Perl
item.description: Is this just a clickbait subject line, or is this saying that 'Some people wanted to change Perl to be something not-Perl, but now the language is saved from those people.'?

item.title: #513 - Perl 5.34.0 is now available!
item.description:
Hi there!

I am disappointed. Mohammad does not like round numbers. He was editing both the 500th edition and the 512th edition and nothing. He did not even blink an eye. I hope he will not forget to celebrate the 1024 edition.

On another note, perl 5.34.0 was released.

I am not saying it is easy, but I really enjoy the live pair programming sessions with Mark Gardner, Upasana Shukla, Juan J. Merelo, Erik Hulsmann, Ferenc Erki, Thomas Klausner, Ynon Perek people whom I know from the Perl community and also Shai Berger, Ivett Ördög, Rachel Normand, Tally Barak, and Laia Asensio López, people I know from other places. One day you might also want to find a partner and try it. It is nice to work with other people who think different from you.

Enjoy your week
